ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I wrote poetry regularly for the first time. I learned a lot about how to develop an idea into a poem, and about how your presence in the world and observations can fuel your poetry. I learned a lot about editing poetry, too-understanding how to participate in a workshop and how to articulate improvements to a poem.
Writing different forms of poetry, how to evaluate others' poetry, poetry writing techniques

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Getting to bring in a new poem a week was an awesome format. I was enough to make the poem feel weighty but not overwhelming. I also liked getting to poke around poems to bring in something I found online or in a book every week, it was a very valuable experience. I wish that the poems we were allowed to bring in could be from a wider range of authors, perhaps going further back in time. I also with the format of sharing the poems we brought in could be a little different because sifting through ~14 poems in an hour meant that we didn't get to focus too much on any one. I also wish the format of critique was a little more open, perhaps more done in small groups, which was how we edited in the last class. I found that format more helpful then the formalized, everyone speaks once and author speaks last version we used in most of class.

Strengths: writing a poem every week is very helpful in being consistent with your writing practice, I also enjoyed the workshops and felt people had helpful feedback, I also enjoyed getting to know a bit about each other through the anthology poems we would bring each week, office hours with Professor Zarin are quite helpful Weaknesses: you don't get much feedback on your work unless you are in workshop or go to Professor Zarin's office hours outside of the midterm and final check-ins

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes- it was an exciting place to get to write and be creative among really smart and interesting people. You will learn a lot from your classmates. It's fun and not incredibly difficult. You get to spend time doing something worthwhile.
If you like reading, writing and discussing poetry, yes. Almost no one gets an A so if you're there for the easy A, don't take it.

Yes, I would. If you want to develop a consistent poetry writing practice, this course will help you do just that. I appreciated coming out of the course with about 13 new poems that had received notes either in workshop or office hours.
